awd_abstract_narration:
The "Emerging STEM Scholars" program at Temple University will address STEM retention and success by providing direct academic support for four years to 48 - 60 academically talented and economically disadvantaged students majoring in biology, biochemistry, or chemistry.  Students will be enrolled in the program during their freshman year, when they are most likely to encounter academic difficulties and change majors.  The program will utilize existing academic support structures and will connect students with specific program content in Temple's first science learning community.  A three tiered mentoring program (undergraduate peers, graduate students, and faculty) will provide support to scholars over their academic career from entry into the institution to graduation.  Scholars will be given access to industry scientists and science career information that will complement academic support and research opportunities.

The project will be based on Tinto's theory of student retention emphasizing both structural supports and content-based and pedagogical supports. Data will be collected to determine what "works" the best, with what type of student, and when.  Research conducted by this project will be both cross-sectional and longitudinal, and will be designed to test the individual and cumulative contributions of the program elements.  The study will also analyze any effect size decay that occurs over time.   Four data sources will provide an academic "map" that will be used to identify patterns that are needed to maintain successful progress to an on-time four-year degree.  The resulting knowledge will be used as the basis for institutional transformation at Temple and other universities.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
The underlying motivation for this project -Emerging STEM Scholars - lied in the need to identify the programming and supports talented but struggling students aspiring to major in a STEM discipline need to succeed, especially those from economically disadvantaged circumstances. The ultimate objective of this project is to bring more undergraduate students into Biology, BioChem, or Chemistry and provide the support needed to prosper. To address this need, the project provided with eight semester long, a four-year curriculum of one-credit, mentor-driven seminars that included external support activities such as included: a three-tier mentoring process, work with university academic support centers, the possibility of early laboratory experience, and regular contact with scientists themselves. Each year’s activities were organized around the following themes: Y1- Forging STEM Relationships; 2 - Becoming STEM Ready; 3 - Active STEM Involvement; and 4 - STEM Ready for the Future. In all, 57 students participated in the two cohorts. While the pandemic did lengthen the time to graduation because of student’s reluctance to enroll in the virtual labs the university established, All of the graduates have enrolled in graduate programs (PhD, MD, DDS) or entered the STEM work force.

Project Adjustments

Three issues surfaced in discussion with project personnel. First, the complete transition to the virtual learning environment meant changes needed to be made in how the seminar course was conducted to accommodate how widely dispersed the students were. Previously, the project personnel had found that scheduling seminars in an institution as large as Temple where students take courses in 10 different colleges (e.g., College of Science and Technology, College of Liberal Arts, School of Business, etc.) and on three different campuses was more challenging than originally thought. After the first semester, better advising alleviated the issue and was not an issue in the 2019-20 truncated academic year and certainly became less of an issue with the move to virtual learning. However, with the students dispersed all over the country (Hawaii included) time differences were an issue for some of the students.

Secondly, it became apparent that preparation for application to university funded research activities needed to start during the Fall semester for both students and faculty. This was successfully done. Among these opportunities are Symposium for Undergraduate Research and Creativity where students present their original research to colleagues and faculty and the Diamond Research Scholars Program where students engage in a focused, mentored research project. Students were expected to apply for these programs. This funded program requires that students a) participate in the all-day Undergraduate Research Institute, b) devote ten weeks during the summer to develop a research project in their area of interest under the direction of their faculty mentor. The TU College of Science and Technology’s Undergraduate Research Program is specifically designed to allow students in CST to work with distinguished Temple faculty members on both the Main campus and the Health Sciences campus to complete hands-on research in their particular field of interest. Unfortunately, these and other university funded research opportunities were postponed due to the university closing in person campus activities.Thirdly, while career and further education issues were covered in the seminars, more was needed than initially thought. The seminars were revised to reflect this.

Focusing on “promising” students proved to be a successful strategy. These students just needed support in terms of knowledge, skills, and perhaps most importantly confidence in that they could attain their “dreams” with a bit more work. The project participants bettered those in the statistical comparison group in terms of grades and post-university activities.

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2023
Modified by: Judith C Stull
